definition:
Let $\X$ be a property of groups, assumed to be an isomorphic invariant
(that is, if a group $G$ has property $\X$, then every group isomorphic
to $G$ also has property $\X$). We shall sometimes refer to groups with
property $\X$ as $\X$-groups.

A group $G$ is said to be *residually $\X$* if for every
$x\in G\backslash\{1\}$ there is a normal subgroup $N$ of $G$ such that
$x\notin N$ and $G/N$ has property $\X$. Equivalently, $G$ is residually
$\X$ if and only if $$\bigcap_{N\normal_\X G}\!\!N=\{1\},$$ where
$N\normal_\X G$ means that $N$ is normal in $G$ and $G/N$ has property
$\X$.

It can be shown that a group is residually $\X$ if and only if it is
isomorphic to a subdirect product of $\X$-groups. If $\X$ is a
hereditary property (that is, every of an $\X$-group is an $\X$-group),
then a group is residually $\X$ if and only if it can be embedded in an
unrestricted direct product of $\X$-groups.

It can be shown that a group $G$ is residually solvable if and only if
the intersection of the derived series of $G$ is trivial (see
transfinite derived series). Similarly, a group $G$ is residually
nilpotent if and only if the intersection of the lower central series of
$G$ is trivial.
